topics.title: Engineers as adults and leadership accountability
topics.summary: Will argues engineers are often "coddled" and sheltered from important work, which limits growth. He sees the current market shift as an opportunity to hold engineers accountable and place them into senior leadership roles.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Will Larson’s background (CTO at Carta; leadership roles at Stripe, Uber, Calm; author of key engineering books) and previews topics they’ll cover.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for DX (developer productivity measurement), OneSchema (CSV importing), and later Vanta (security compliance automation).

topics.title: What’s changing in engineering post-ZIRP
topics.summary: Will contrasts the hypergrowth era (constant hiring) with today’s slowdown (few interviews, team consolidations). He notes managers must now demonstrate leadership, prioritization, and org-sizing skills rather than just hiring prowess.

topics.title: Engineer leverage, coddling, and senior roles
topics.summary: They discuss how reduced engineer leverage can reduce coddling and enable clearer accountability. Will connects this to unlocking senior IC roles (e.g., Staff Engineer) by expecting engineers to own hard, business-critical problems.

topics.title: Systems thinking: definition and pitfalls
topics.summary: Will defines systems thinking as modeling stocks and flows, and warns against over-committing to models when reality disagrees. He shares a Stripe incident-management example where measurement crowded out actual improvement work.

topics.title: Applying systems thinking to hiring pipelines
topics.summary: Will maps hiring as a stock-and-flow system (sourcing → screens → offers → accepts) and explains how modeling reveals bottlenecks like low offer conviction or poor closing. The goal is to target fixes based on observed drop-offs rather than vibes.

topics.title: Engineering strategy: write it down and embrace boring
topics.summary: Will argues every org has a strategy even if it’s unwritten; writing enables debugging alignment and execution. He emphasizes that good engineering strategy is often "boring" constraints (e.g., standard toolkits) that focus energy on what matters.

topics.title: Strategy examples: constraints at Uber and Stripe
topics.summary: Will shares concrete strategy constraints: Uber’s “no cloud” policy enabling rapid geopolitical expansion, and Stripe’s Ruby monolith focusing effort on customer value over tooling sprawl. They discuss strategy as choosing constraints to allocate limited capacity.

topics.title: How to get better at strategy
topics.summary: Will recommends foundational strategy and systems books (Rumelt’s Good Strategy Bad Strategy; Meadows’ Thinking in Systems) plus engineering-adjacent strategy texts. He notes a gap in a canonical engineering strategy book and hints at writing one.

topics.title: Writing output: motivation, energy, and longevity
topics.summary: Will explains he writes what energizes him, avoids rigid schedules, and stops projects that don’t cohere. Lenny and Will discuss playing the long game, avoiding trend-chasing, and sustaining quality by staying in one’s lane.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Vanta sponsor read about streamlining security compliance (SOC 2, ISO 27001, HIPAA, etc.) with automation and a listener discount.

topics.title: Tactical writing workflow with a demanding job
topics.summary: Will estimates ~1,000 posts and explains he aligns writing with work problems to improve thinking and performance. He describes shifting from weekend writing pre-kids to nighttime writing, emphasizing energy as the limiting factor.

topics.title: Advice for aspiring writers: artifacts vs consistency
topics.summary: Will advises career-advancers to write 2–3 excellent pieces rather than start a newsletter, while consistent writers should publish frequently and not over-optimize quality early. They discuss ignoring unhelpful feedback and the low stakes of early publishing.

topics.title: Improving PM–engineering relationships and incentives
topics.summary: Will identifies two common issues: misaligned incentives and lack of understanding of each other’s true needs. He suggests aligning EM/PM accountability (including experimenting with shared performance outcomes) and focusing on deeper needs to find win-win solutions.
